posts.cooked:
so currently for our code to run our elevator and arm combo I just have two joysticks for the co-driver to use to align the pair on a scoring place or the human player station. This is partially because I have no clue how to go about making more automated controls for the elevator and arm. Most of my problem with doing this is making the end effector not bonk into the human player shelf, the grid, or the bumpers. As it would do if I just let it go diagonally. How would I go about programming this?

we’re using java. 3100-Robotics/robot-2023: 3100’s code for he 2023 season (github.com) I also have a branch on our code with my best attempt at this but it is somewhat broken.

posts.name: Milan Lustig
posts.cooked:
From what I understand, it seems like you want to run the elevator then the arm (or vice versa). Assuming this, to automate positions, I would make three commands. One command to extend the arm to a given position, one command to move the elevator to a certain position, and finally, a SequentialCommandGroup to chain the other two commands together. Here are the WPILib docs on sequential command groups.

Looking at your code, it appears you use PID controllers on your arm/elevator which should allow you to create a command to set the PIDs to a desired position and run the motor with the given output.

Essentially, the SequentialCommandGroup will run other commands added to it sequentially, that is, it will schedule one after another upon finishing. You could build multiple SequentialCommandGroup that use various combinations of the aforementioned arm and elevator movement commands to move your whole system to different locations (ie substation, upper, mid, etc). These different SequentialCommandGroup could then be bound to buttons on your controller.

Here is an example of a SequentialCommandGroup my team used last year (this one was to chain autonomous movement commands).

Hope this helps!

link_counts.title: Command Groups — FIRST Robotics Competition documentation

posts.name: Mason Vogt
posts.cooked: I did a large chunk of this control work for my team (2129) and would be happy to help you figure out presets that work well for your team. I had a really great time driving with you guys at North Star and would love to help improve your controls!

So, while sequentially running the commands would work, its what I’ve done with autonomous. part of the point for this is to be more efficient than a normal driver. So I would like to be able to go diagonally but something like running both the elevator and arm the same speed will crash into things so you need some way to make it know this and have it move at a different diagonal.

given this image, the red line is what you are suggesting its probably the longest of them all. The green one is the one I want to avoid as it intersects the mid post. The blue one is more like what I want our arm and elevator pair to do.

posts.name: Milan Lustig
posts.cooked:
It seems you want the arm to initially extend slower (or just not all the way out) until the elevator reaches its top position.

I would change from solely a sequential command group to both a sequential and parallel group. In the parallel group, I would add a command to fully extend the elevator and another to partially extend the arm. In the sequential command group, I would first schedule the parallel group then schedule another command to finish extending the arm. You could also make some other combinations of parallel and sequential groups (ie first lift elevator a bit, then do both elevator and arm at the same time)

The other way to do this would be to write some code to fully extend the elevator and the arm at the same time, but slow the arm until the elevator is fully extended. It seems like you already have multiple PIDs for moving up/down, so you could add another PID configuration to slow the movement initially.

Both methods might work, so I think it’s just up to personal preference.

Edit: also, sorry for not giving any code examples, I’m on mobile currently so it’s a bit tough.

now, if our life was simple this would work great but our life isn’t quite so simple. Here’s a few more examples to show why. if the elevator is already up, our blue line will still work but the green line is now more efficient because it no longer goes through the middle post. here if our end effector is up at the high post and we see that the cone won’t be able to get onto it we would need to move to the mid post. Here Red will still work, though it could act more like the maroon line with no mods. The green line, again, runs through the mid post so our ideal is something like blue. now, here we are at the human player station and we want to go up to pick up the cone. Green obviously does not work because it intersects the station. Here it may actually be better to use the red movement because blue will cut awffully close to the corner of the station. In this example, we want to get to the purple point. Finally, we need to think about getting outside of the bumpers. Here the green line will try to make the end effector run through the bumpers. Red, as usual will work but it won’t be fast. So, we would prefer to use blue. This is where I have gotten stuck as I need to figure out a clean way to logic through what the optimal movement would be for a given position of the end effector and the end position.

posts.name: Mason Vogt
posts.cooked:
Our team also ran into problems with hitting on the way up to a position. Because we had a 971-style double-jointed arm, we just ran with an intermediate position that the arm would go to before reaching its final destination.

In your case, I would recommend that you have a controller that can run both segments using kinematics of some sort, and that would let you simply give it a formula of x,y positions, and it could follow that.

Another simpler option would be to prematurely elevate the elevator to the correct height before you are even scoring or going to the substation as unlike our arm, yours can move without being illegal in the center of the field.

so the wpilib docs describe kinematics as something that converts raw speeds into velocities for the sides of the robot. Would these kinematics take the start and end position and convert them into a set of translations to take?

posts.name: Allen Nuttle
posts.cooked:
We do most of the work in a Periodic() routine.  Commands either just update one or both of the target positions, or update and then wait for both of the positions to be achieved.

We run PID (really, profiled P, with I and D zero) on the RIO.  This way, we can use more complicated feedforward to compensate for gravity, and we can make decisions for each of the joints, considering both of the current positions and the computed output for each motor.

Here’s where this helps in this type of scenario…  We have soft limits on each joint (these even activate in stages: as the target is approached, the output is limited and then fully stopped).  We also have limits that apply to the position of the joints.  For example, using a human arm as the model, the wrist/hand going into a certain region is treated as a limit.

When these limits are reached, the outputs are adjusted so that the overall arm continues to move generally in the desired direction, but one of the joints may be temporarily moved in such a way as to keep the wrist/hand out of the limit region.

posts.name: Mason Vogt
posts.cooked:
Yes, this is what the kinematics would do. This is completely different from the wpilib kinematics. In the case of this robot, it is really simple, the y translation is just the elevator elevation, and the x translation is just the forearm extension.

You wouldn’t really need to know where the arm currently is as pid will handle that for you.

posts.name: Mason Vogt
posts.cooked: I’m working on a simulated demo of what I mean on a fork of the original project.

posts.name: Milan Lustig
posts.cooked:
As Mason_V said, what you want sounds like some pretty complex Inverse Kinematics. Honestly, (I’m a lazy programmer), I would just have multiple different configurations bound to multiple different buttons. Ie one button to do elevator then arm, one to do arm then elevator, etc.

Inverse Kinematics are pretty difficult but extremely powerful if you can get them down, there are lots of resources online on how to do it. Because you want to vary the paths with environmental factors, you would still need multiple configurations for substation vs grid, etc.

Inverse Kinematics is essentially the calculation of movements of different joints to reach a desired position.

Hope this helps!

unfortunately, the point of this is not to be lazy… I’m sorta doing it to learn how to do it and sorta doing it because it’s interesting. So I shall go off and research how to create inverse kinematics for our arm and elevator pair.
We use trapezoidal motion profiling to control our elevator, arm, and wrist system, and have found it to work quite well. You can take a look at our code to start if you’d like.

posts.name: Mason Vogt
posts.cooked: I think you got me wrong, this is about the simplest inverse kinematics you can do.

posts.name: Mason Vogt
posts.cooked:
I’ve put a draft pull request on the repo with your 2023 code. This pull request isn’t really meant to be merged and certainly isn’t ready yet but instead, use it as inspiration. Take the bits that you like about it and leave the rest.

You may also find some useful stuff in our code , especially the arm controls. I’ll continue to add to this fork and further comment my changes so that you can learn from them.

posts.name: Milan Lustig
posts.cooked: My bad, I was more referring to IK that would “avoid” a certain coordinate/line (ie travel above it). Looking at your pull request, this pretty much seems to be chaining “move to position” commands (IK) but still wouldn’t solve the issue of avoiding the grid unless there were multiple configurations created (if I’m wrong - I’m sorry, it’s possible I missed something in the code). Thank you for phrasing it so much better than I did and giving example code. I hope this clears up what I meant!

posts.name: Mason Vogt
posts.cooked:
I haven’t done anything to avoid obstacles yet; that is tomorrow’s challenge. Our team had a bunch of logic for calculating intermediate positions to avoid moving our double-jointed arm into illegal positions, but for a robot that can’t do these positions, I think one simple hard-coded intermediate position through a sequential command and a larger tolerance would do the trick just fine.

Through our team’s many hours of practice, we found that an intermediate position wasn’t necessary for avoiding the substation as we would just move to that position earlier. For scoring on the grid, only high scoring was an issue for us so we moved the arm to the correct height but just 0.6 meters out so as not to hit anything on the way up.

So looking at the code There’s going to be one problem with it. The movement of the inner stage of our elevator isn’t linear (Its super annoying) because of how our rope holding the inner stage is rigged. Thus there isn’t a super simple way to convert ticks to feet. Also rev encoders work in rotations not ticks.

edit: Oh and as for the “really jank” solution in the drive command, yeah its jank but it does the job of slowing down the robot the higher the elevator is. If you got a better idea for that please tell me but that worked for all of our last comp.
